I refer to a study entitled "Cross-National Correlations of Quantifiable Societal Health with Popular Religiosity and Secularism in the Prosperous Democracies," carried out by Gregory S. Paul and published in the Journal of Religion and Society, as quoted in Skeptic magazine.
 
 In brief, the research finds positive correlation between national religiosity and incidence of homicide, teenage pregnancy and abortion (see attached graphs). Percentage of population accepting the theory of evolution shows a negative correlation with homicide rate (the others aren't graphed, but would also show negative correlation.)
 
 We are all well aware that correlation isn't causation, and I don't think the author or anyone else is claiming that high levels of religiosity necessarily cause social dysfunction. It may be that inherently dysfunctional societies are more driven to religiosity; it may be that both are manifestations of some deeper aspect of the society's structure. Either way, what this and similar studies do achieve is to pull the rug from under evangelical christians' railing against the evils of secularism and the awful consequences of teaching children about evolution. As the Skeptic article concludes,
 
What we can be clear about from this study is that highly religious societies can be dysfunctional, whereas by comparison secular societies in which evolution is largely accepted display real social cohesion and societal well-being.
